countries.name: Spain
countries.summary:
Pedro Sánchez is hanging on by his fingernails. The PSOE prime minister's minority coalition with Sumar depends on a patchwork of regional parties—Catalan separatists, Basque nationalists, even the radical left of EH Bildu. But in late October 2025, Junts per Catalunya, the Catalan independence party, voted unanimously to sever ties with the government. Without Junts' seven seats, Sánchez can't reliably pass legislation or budgets. He's now governing on borrowed time, facing the very real threat of a no-confidence vote that could trigger snap elections.

The irony is bitter. Sánchez came to power in 2018 promising democratic renewal after the corruption scandals of the Rajoy years. Now his government is drowning in its own sleaze. The Koldo case—involving former Transport Minister José Luis Ábalos and the PSOE's organizational secretary Santos Cerdán—has exposed an alleged corruption network at the heart of the party. Add to that investigations into Sánchez's wife and brother, and the stench of impropriety is everywhere. V-Dem's democracy indices tell the story: Spain's rating has dropped from 0.78 in 2018 to 0.75 in 2024, with political corruption up 178% and executive corruption up an astonishing 540%. The PP leader Alberto Núñez Feijóo is polling ahead nationally, positioning himself as the man to clean house.

But here's the thing about Spanish politics—it's gloriously dysfunctional. Congress remains hopelessly fragmented. The far-right Vox party, despite losing some momentum, still commands around 30 seats and opposes everything from immigration to regional autonomy. Even if Sánchez falls, forming a stable alternative government won't be easy. Feijóo would need Vox's support, which would alienate moderate voters. And the Catalan question refuses to die. Sánchez's amnesty law for separatist leaders—the very policy that won him Junts' support initially—has become toxic. Regional elections in Catalonia earlier in 2025 saw the Socialist PSC's Salvador Illa become president, but pro-independence sentiment hasn't evaporated; it's just shifted tactics.

Looking ahead, the question is whether Sánchez can survive until the scheduled 2027 elections. He's a survivor—he's navigated six years of coalition chaos—but his room for maneuver is shrinking. The corruption investigations won't go away. The opposition smells blood. And the Spanish public, according to polls, is tired of the drama. Expect Sánchez to try to buy off Junts with more concessions on Catalonia, though that risks alienating other coalition partners. The alternative is calling elections and hoping for a miracle.

The bottom line? Spain's democracy is creaking. Not collapsing, but creaking. The institutions still function, the press is free, but the political class has lost credibility. Whoever wins the next election—whether it's Feijóo, Sánchez, or some unholy coalition—will inherit a country skeptical of its politicians and deeply divided on identity, corruption, and the very meaning of Spain itself. It's not the worst crisis Spain has faced, but it's the kind of slow rot that can hollow out a democracy from within.

countries.name: Sri Lanka
countries.summary:
Something extraordinary happened in Sri Lanka in November 2024, and a year on we're still processing what it means. Anura Kumara Dissanayake—a Marxist-leaning politician from the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP), leading the National People's Power (NPP) alliance—didn't just win the presidency in September 2024. His party then captured 159 of 225 parliamentary seats in November, a two-thirds supermajority. This in a country where the NPP had won just three seats four years earlier with under 4% of the vote. It's the kind of electoral earthquake that reshapes politics for a generation.

What makes this truly remarkable is where the NPP won. For the first time in Sri Lankan history, a southern, Sinhala-dominated party swept the Tamil-majority Northern and Eastern provinces—areas scarred by civil war, where ethnic parties had always prevailed. Voters in Jaffna and Batticaloa, who'd lost family members to the Sri Lankan military, backed Dissanayake's anti-corruption, anti-elite message. The old politics of ethnic patronage collapsed overnight. The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP), which had won a landslide in 2020, was decimated. The Samagi Jana Balawegaya (SJB), the main opposition, held just 40 seats. Former president Ranil Wickremesinghe's New Democratic Front managed a humiliating three seats.

But here's the rub: winning is the easy part. Dissanayake has less than four years left in his five-year term, and the manifesto promises are staggeringly ambitious. Abolish the executive presidency. Renegotiate the IMF program to provide "fairer terms" for ordinary Sri Lankans. Establish a director of public prosecutions to tackle judicial delays. Deliver accountability for the 2019 Easter Sunday attacks. Repeal the draconian Prevention of Terrorism Act. The list goes on. A year in, the government has made some progress on transparency and tackling low-level corruption, but the big structural reforms haven't materialized. The IMF program continues largely unchanged—because the debt crisis leaves no room for maneuver. The executive presidency remains intact. And the PTA is still on the books.

The opposition is in disarray, which gives Dissanayake political space but also removes accountability. The traditional parties—UNP, SLFP, SLPP—are in existential crisis, led by aging politicians clinging to past glories. The SJB, led by Sajith Premadasa, is the only credible opposition, but they've struggled to articulate a vision beyond "we're not the NPP." This two-thirds majority could be a blessing or a curse. It gives Dissanayake the numbers to pass constitutional reforms, but it also means he owns the outcomes. If the economy stalls, if corruption persists, if the Tamil question remains unresolved, there's no one else to blame.

The big test is whether the NPP can move beyond rhetoric to delivery. Can they renegotiate debt sustainably without spooking creditors? Can they boost growth while maintaining fiscal discipline? Can they reconcile with Tamil communities without alienating the Sinhala base? These are wicked problems with no easy answers. The goodwill is there—for now. But Sri Lankan voters are pragmatic. They gave Dissanayake a mandate because the old elite failed catastrophically, triggering the 2022 economic collapse. If the NPP doesn't deliver tangible improvements in the next three years, the backlash will be swift.

Bottom line: Sri Lanka has kicked out the old political class, which is democratically healthy. But replacing them with new faces doesn't solve the underlying economic fragility or ethnic divisions. The NPP's success will be measured not by election results, but by whether they can build institutions that outlast any single leader. That's the harder, slower work—and the jury's still out.

countries.name: Sudan
countries.summary:
There is no politics in Sudan right now. There's war, and there's survival, and there's the slow-motion collapse of what was once a functioning state. Since April 2023, Sudan has been consumed by a brutal civil war between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), commanded by General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, known as Hemedti. More than 150,000 people are dead. Over 14 million have been displaced. Famine is spreading across Darfur. This isn't a conflict about ideology or governance; it's a raw power struggle between two military factions, each backed by regional powers, each willing to destroy Sudan to control it.

The trajectory of the war has been grim. In October 2025, the RSF captured El Fasher, the last major city in Darfur outside its control. Reports of massacres—hundreds of civilians executed in the aftermath—paint a picture of genocidal violence. The RSF, a paramilitary force grown out of the Jangaweed militias that terrorized Darfur in the 2000s, controls much of Khartoum and western Sudan. But the SAF isn't innocent. It recaptured Khartoum in March 2025 through brutal urban warfare, leveling neighborhoods. Both sides have committed atrocities. Both have blocked humanitarian aid. Both claim to represent Sudan's legitimate government. Neither has any interest in a political settlement.

The international response has been pathetic. U.S.-led ceasefire talks involving Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and the UAE produced a proposal in November 2025. The RSF nominally agreed, but the SAF dismissed it, demanding the RSF withdraw from civilian areas first—a non-starter. SAF chief Burhan has rejected negotiations entirely, insisting the RSF are terrorists who must be militarily defeated. Meanwhile, foreign powers fuel the conflict. The UAE stands accused of arming the RSF through Chad and the Central African Republic. Egypt backs the SAF with diplomatic support and possibly weapons. Saudi Arabia tries to play mediator but lacks leverage. The UN warns of "intensified hostilities," but there's no enforcement mechanism. The African Union is sidelined. Geneva talks collapsed.

Civilian politicians—the pro-democracy activists who led the 2019 revolution against Omar al-Bashir and briefly held power in the transitional government—have been completely sidelined. Many are in exile. Those who remain have no influence over either military faction. The dream of a democratic Sudan, which felt within reach in 2019-2020, is dead. The question now is whether Sudan survives as a single country. The RSF controls Darfur and parts of the west. The SAF holds Port Sudan, the Red Sea coast, and some central areas. Kurdish forces control bits of the east. It's de facto partition, and it's hard to see how you put this back together.

The humanitarian catastrophe is almost beyond comprehension. Two regions are in famine. Disease outbreaks are rampant. Schools and hospitals have been destroyed. The economy has collapsed—no government functions, no tax collection, no basic services. Sudan was already one of the poorest countries in the world before the war. Now it's a failed state, and the international community has moved on. Ukraine gets headlines. Gaza gets attention. Sudan gets a paragraph on page 12.

Bottom line: This war will grind on until one side collapses or both realize they can't win. That could take years. In the meantime, Sudan bleeds. When the war finally ends, the task of rebuilding won't be political reconciliation or democratic transition—it'll be basic state-building from rubble. Whoever governs Sudan next won't be a president; they'll be a warlord or a strongman. Democracy isn't on the table. Survival is.
issues: El Fasher massacre and genocide fears

countries.name: Sweden
countries.summary:
Sweden's center-right government, led by Moderate Party Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson, is two years into the most significant political experiment in modern Swedish history: governing with the parliamentary support of the Sweden Democrats (SD), a party with roots in the neo-Nazi movement. It's a Faustian bargain. The Sweden Democrats don't sit in the cabinet—Kristersson's coalition formally consists of the Moderates, Christian Democrats, and Liberals—but they provide the votes needed to pass legislation. And in return, they shape policy. On immigration. On crime. On integration. SD's influence is everywhere, and Swedish politics has fundamentally changed.

The surprising thing is how stable it's been. Kristersson's coalition was expected to implode within months, torn apart by internal contradictions. The Liberals, a centrist party with roots in classical liberalism, would surely revolt at being tied to SD's anti-immigration agenda, right? Wrong. Two years on, the government is functioning. Dozens of inquiries into migration tightening have been launched. Gang violence, a genuine crisis in Swedish cities, is being tackled with tougher policing and criminal justice reforms. Nuclear power expansion is on the agenda. NATO membership—Sweden joined in March 2024 after Turkish and Hungarian delays—has been smoothly integrated. Kristersson has proven a steady, if uninspiring, hand on the tiller.

But 2025 is the "ox year"—Swedish political slang for a year when the government must deliver results. The 2026 election is on the horizon, and voters will judge whether this right-wing experiment was worth the moral compromise. The Social Democrats, led by Magdalena Andersson, are polling competitively. They're painting the government as beholden to extremists, pointing to SD's continued inflammatory rhetoric on immigration and Islam. Meanwhile, the Liberals face an existential question: Can they participate in a government that includes the Sweden Democrats after 2026? The party is hemorrhaging support—polls show them hovering near the 4% threshold for parliamentary representation. Their national meeting in late November 2025 will be decisive. If they break with Kristersson, the coalition collapses.

The Sweden Democrats, for their part, are consolidating as Sweden's kingmaker. With around 20% of the vote, they're the third-largest party, and their demands grow bolder. They've shifted from immigration alone to broader cultural and economic issues. They want tougher integration requirements for citizenship—speaking Swedish, loyalty oaths, cultural tests. They've floated ideas about limiting mosque construction and banning certain Islamic practices. This is the price Kristersson pays for their support. And it's reshaping what's politically acceptable in Sweden. Discourse that would've been taboo five years ago is now mainstream.

The debate over Sweden's relationship with the EU is also intensifying. The SD is Eurosceptic, and while Sweden won't leave the EU—public support for membership is strong—there's growing appetite for a more transactional relationship. Sweden isn't adopting the euro, and there's resistance to further EU integration. Immigration policy, where Sweden has one of the toughest stances in the EU now, is a flashpoint. The Swedish government argues it's simply correcting past mistakes, when Sweden took in more asylum seekers per capita than almost any European country during the 2015 migration crisis. Critics say it's betraying Sweden's humanitarian tradition.

Bottom line: Swedish politics has moved right, and it's not moving back. The Social Democrats may win in 2026, but they won't reverse the shift on immigration or crime. The Sweden Democrats have changed the conversation permanently. The question is whether Swedish democracy can absorb a party with extremist roots without losing its soul. So far, the institutions are holding. The judiciary is independent. The press is free. But the normalization of the SD is real. In ten years, we'll look back at this period as the moment Sweden stopped being the progressive exception in Europe and became, well, more normal. Whether that's progress or decline depends on your perspective.

countries.name: Switzerland
countries.summary:
Swiss politics operates on a different plane. While the rest of Europe lurches from crisis to coalition collapse, Switzerland hums along with its seven-member Federal Council, rotating presidency, and 170-year-old "magic formula" ensuring all major parties share power. Karin Keller-Sutter of the FDP (Free Democratic Party) is serving as president in 2025—a largely ceremonial role that rotates annually. The real power lies in the collective: two seats each for the Swiss People's Party (SVP), Social Democrats (SP), and FDP, plus one seat for The Centre party. It's consensus politics, Swiss-style, and it's maddeningly effective.

The big news in 2025 was the resignation of Viola Amherd, The Centre's representative and defense minister, announced in January and effective in March. Before she quit, the SVP had been piling pressure on her, criticizing her handling of defense procurement and her perceived softness on neutrality issues. The SVP, Switzerland's largest party with 27.9% of the vote, doesn't like Amherd's openness to European security cooperation in the wake of Ukraine. They see it as drift from Switzerland's sacred neutrality. Martin Pfister, also from The Centre, was elected to replace her in March 2025. But the SVP's attacks signal a broader tension: how does Switzerland navigate a world where neutrality feels increasingly untenable?

Switzerland's direct democracy means politics happens at the ballot box, not just in Bern. Referendums are held multiple times a year on everything from biodiversity initiatives to energy policy. In September 2025, voters weighed in on a biodiversity proposal, and immigration debates continue to dominate. The SVP, the populist-right party that's been the largest in parliament since 2003, drives the immigration agenda. They want tighter controls, skepticism of EU free movement, and a "Switzerland first" approach. It's not far-right in the European sense—no Le Pen-style nationalism—but it's hardline on sovereignty and identity.

The elephant in the room is the EU. Switzerland isn't a member, but it's enmeshed in hundreds of bilateral treaties covering trade, movement, and regulation. The relationship is a nightmare to manage—every few years, Brussels threatens to walk away unless Switzerland accepts dynamic alignment with EU rules. The Swiss response is: "We'll think about it." In 2025, negotiations continue on updating the framework, but domestic politics makes concessions difficult. The SVP opposes anything resembling EU integration. The left and trade unions worry about wage protection. The business community wants access to the single market but hates the regulatory burden. Finding consensus is like herding Swiss cows uphill.

Neutrality is the other flashpoint. Switzerland froze Russian assets after the Ukraine invasion—a major departure from strict neutrality. The SVP was furious, arguing Switzerland had compromised its credibility as a neutral mediator. The SP and Greens said neutrality doesn't mean moral equivalence. The debate cuts to Swiss identity: Are they a values-based liberal democracy that must stand against aggression, or a pragmatic neutral state that stays out of conflicts? There's no easy answer, and the 2024 referendum on whether to provide arms to Ukraine (rejected) showed the public is deeply divided.

Despite all this, Swiss politics is remarkably stable. The Federal Council system prevents any one party from dominating. The SVP, despite being the largest party, can't impose its will—it needs coalition partners. The left can block rightward drift through referendums. And Swiss institutions—the judiciary, the cantons, the civil service—are robust and trusted. Corruption is virtually nonexistent. Turnout in referendums is often low (30-40%), but that's because the system works; people trust it.

Bottom line: Switzerland is proof that boring politics is a blessing. No political earthquakes. No strongmen. No democratic backsliding. Just grinding consensus, referendum campaigns, and incremental change. The challenges—EU relations, neutrality, immigration—aren't going away, but they'll be solved Swiss-style: slowly, pragmatically, and with maximum public input. If the rest of Europe had Switzerland's problems, they'd count themselves lucky.
issues: Viola Amherd resignation and SVP pressure
Direct democracy on biodiversity and energy

countries.name: Syria
countries.summary:
Syria just rewrote its entire history, and nobody saw it coming. Bashar al-Assad—president since 2000, dictator since day one, the man who survived a decade-long civil war that killed half a million people and displaced 13 million—fell in December 2024. Not through Western intervention. Not through prolonged siege. But through a lightning rebel offensive that began on November 27, 2024, and within two weeks had toppled the regime. Assad fled to Russia, granted asylum by his longtime patron Vladimir Putin. The Assad dynasty, which ruled Syria for 54 years, ended with barely a whimper.

The new leadership is led by Ahmed al-Sharaa, formerly the head of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham (HTS), a jihadist group with roots in al-Qaeda. Yes, you read that right. A former al-Qaeda affiliate now runs Syria. But here's the twist: al-Sharaa has reinvented himself as a pragmatic nationalist, shedding the jihadist label and positioning HTS as a stabilizing force. An interim government was declared in March 2025, with a new constitutional framework promising elections—eventually. The West is cautiously engaging. In November 2025, al-Sharaa visited Washington to meet President Trump, a remarkable normalization for a man who spent years on terrorism watchlists. He also attended the UN Climate Conference in Brazil, Syria's first participation in the summit. The message: We're a normal country now.

But scratch the surface, and it's chaos. Syria is fragmented. The northeast is controlled by the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a Kurdish-led militia backed by the U.S. Turkey occupies parts of the north. Israel has conducted airstrikes targeting Iranian positions. Idlib, once the opposition stronghold, is under al-Sharaa's control, but whether the rest of Syria accepts his authority is an open question. The economy is in ruins—90% of the population lives in poverty. Infrastructure is destroyed. There's no electricity, no water systems, no functioning health care in vast swathes of the country. Rebuilding will cost hundreds of billions of dollars. Who's paying?

Sanctions are being lifted, slowly. The UK, EU, and U.S. have progressively removed sanctions on Syria's central bank and energy companies, trying to facilitate economic recovery. But sanctions on military goods and individuals linked to Assad-era crimes remain. The West wants to support Syria's transition without empowering warlords or allowing Iranian entrenchment. It's a delicate balance. Gulf states—Saudi Arabia, UAE—are cautiously investing, but they want guarantees. They don't trust al-Sharaa's jihadist past, and they fear Syria becoming another Libya: a failed state with competing militias.

The regional dynamics have flipped. Iran, which propped up Assad for a decade, is out. Hezbollah, which sent fighters to defend Damascus, has been sidelined. Russia, which provided airpower that turned the civil war in Assad's favor, retains its naval base at Tartus but has lost political influence. Turkey is the big winner, backing Syrian factions and extending its influence. The Gulf states are positioning themselves as economic patrons. Israel watches nervously, having grown comfortable with a weak Assad; a strong, Islamist-led Syria is a different proposition.

The big question is whether al-Sharaa can transition from rebel leader to statesman. HTS, despite the rebranding, has an authoritarian streak. Political dissent in Idlib under their rule was suppressed. Can they build pluralistic institutions? Will they allow free elections? And what about accountability for Assad-era crimes—chemical attacks, torture, mass starvation? The new government says all the right things, but actions matter more than words. There's talk of a truth and reconciliation process, but Syria is deeply scarred. Alawites, who formed the base of Assad's regime, fear retribution. Christians and Druze worry about Islamist rule. Kurds want autonomy. Sunni Arabs, the majority, want power restored after decades of Alawite dominance.

Bottom line: Syria's future is wide open, and that's terrifying and hopeful in equal measure. The fall of Assad is unambiguously good—he was a butcher. But what comes next? Nobody knows. The optimistic scenario: al-Sharaa pragmatically rebuilds, holds elections, integrates minorities, and Syria slowly emerges from catastrophe. The pessimistic scenario: factionalism, warlordism, renewed conflict, and Syria fragments into a patchwork of competing statelets. Right now, it could go either way. The world should pay attention. Syria's trajectory will shape the Middle East for a generation.
issues: Fall of Assad regime in December 2024
Regional power vacuum (Iran out, Turkey in)

countries.name: Taiwan
countries.summary:
Lai Ching-te is Taiwan's president, but he doesn't control the legislature, and that matters. The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) retained the presidency in January 2024, breaking historical patterns—no party had won three consecutive presidential terms since Taiwan's democratization. But the Legislative Yuan is another story. The Kuomintang (KMT) and Taiwan People's Party (TPP) together hold 60 seats versus the DPP's 51, giving the opposition leverage to block Lai's agenda. It's divided government, Taiwanese-style, and it's become a nightmare for governance. Lai can't pass budgets, can't enact reforms, can't even get routine appointments approved without KMT cooperation. And the KMT isn't cooperating.

The situation got worse in November 2025 when the KMT elected a new chairwoman, Cheng Li-wun. Cheng represents the KMT's pro-Beijing wing. She's openly skeptical of defense spending increases, opposes the DPP's arms purchases, and has said she'd meet Xi Jinping "a hundred times" to resolve cross-strait disputes peacefully. This isn't subtle. The KMT, historically the party of Chiang Kai-shek and anti-communism, has repositioned itself as the party of engagement with China. Not unification—that's still toxic in Taiwanese politics—but accommodation. Cheng's rhetoric unnerves Washington, which sees Taiwan as the linchpin of Indo-Pacific security. A KMT-led Taiwan might not resist Chinese pressure as firmly.

Lai, meanwhile, is trying to boost defense spending. He wants to push military budgets above 3% of GDP, aiming for 5% by 2030. The U.S. has been pressuring Taiwan to do more, arguing that Taiwan's survival depends on deterring a Chinese invasion. But the KMT-controlled legislature is blocking it. Cheng argues that defense spending escalates tensions, that Taiwan should pursue dialogue instead of militarization. The DPP counters that dialogue from weakness invites aggression. It's the core debate in Taiwanese politics: How do you deal with an existential threat from a vastly more powerful neighbor?

The DPP tried to break the legislative deadlock in summer 2025 with an unprecedented recall campaign. Civil society groups, openly backed by President Lai, launched the "Great Recall," targeting 31 KMT legislators. The goal was to flip enough seats to regain a majority. It was a gamble, and it failed spectacularly. By August, not a single KMT legislator had been recalled. Voters saw it as overreach, and the DPP's approval ratings took a hit. The KMT crowed about defending democracy from executive overreach. It was a humiliating defeat for Lai, and it emboldened the opposition. Since then, the legislature has been even more obstructionist.

Cross-strait tensions remain high. China conducts near-daily military flights in Taiwan's air defense identification zone. Grey-zone tactics—coast guard harassment, cyber attacks, disinformation campaigns—are constant. But there's no imminent invasion. Beijing is playing the long game, trying to isolate Taiwan diplomatically, squeeze it economically, and undermine public confidence in independence. Lai's response is to deepen ties with the U.S., Japan, and European democracies. Unofficial visits by foreign parliamentarians have increased. Taiwan's semiconductor industry, the crown jewel of the global economy, gives Taipei leverage. Nobody wants TSMC's chip fabs in Chinese hands.

But here's the uncomfortable truth: Taiwan's politics is deeply polarized, and that's a strategic vulnerability. The DPP and KMT can't agree on defense policy, on China policy, on constitutional reform, on anything. Lai's presidency is weakened by legislative gridlock. The 2026 local elections will be a crucial test. If the KMT does well, they'll claim a mandate for their approach. If the DPP rebounds, Lai gets breathing room. Either way, Taiwan's democracy is vibrant but fractious—a strength when demonstrating resilience, a weakness when trying to present unified deterrence.

Bottom line: Taiwan is stable for now, but the political dysfunction is real. Divided government isn't fatal, but it hampers Taiwan's ability to prepare for worst-case scenarios. China is watching. If Beijing concludes that Taiwanese politics are too divided to mount effective resistance, the calculus for invasion shifts. Taiwan needs to get its act together—not just militarily, but politically. That means DPP and KMT finding common ground on defense, even if they disagree on everything else. So far, that common ground is elusive. And the clock is ticking.
issues: KMT's new pro-Beijing chair Cheng Li-wun

countries.name: Tanzania
countries.summary:
Samia Suluhu Hassan has secured her grip on power, but it's a grim kind of victory. Tanzania held presidential and parliamentary elections on October 29, 2025, and Hassan—who became president in 2021 after John Magufuli's sudden death—was declared the winner with a preposterous 97.66% of the vote. Turnout was reported at 87%, which in any functional democracy would trigger alarm bells. The two largest opposition parties, Chadema and the Alliance for Change and Transparency (ACT), were barred from participating. Their leaders were jailed, their campaigns shut down. This wasn't an election; it was a coronation.

The violence that followed was brutal. On election day, protests erupted in Dar es Salaam, Arusha, and Mwanza as demonstrators tried to stop the counting of votes. The government sent in police and, reportedly, military units. Casualty figures are contested. The UN human rights office says at least 10 people were killed. Chadema, the main opposition party, claims hundreds died. The truth is likely somewhere in between, but the point is: people died protesting an election they saw as a sham. The Southern African Development Community (SADC), which sent election observers, released a damning preliminary statement. The election didn't meet SADC standards for credibility, freedom, or fairness. Intimidation, restricted political participation, and serious deficits in transparency were rampant.

Hassan was sworn in on November 3, 2025, at a military base in Dodoma—a symbolic choice. She gave a defiant speech, praising the election as free and fair, dismissing criticism as foreign interference. The international response has been muted. Western governments issued tepid statements of concern. The African Union said nothing. Tanzania isn't strategically vital enough for anyone to care deeply, and Hassan knows it. She's calculated that she can weather the diplomatic fallout. And so far, she's right.

The tragedy is that Hassan's first two years in office were different. When she took over in 2021, she represented hope. Magufuli had been a disaster—autocratic, anti-science (he denied COVID-19 existed), hostile to press freedom. Hassan promised reforms. She reopened media outlets, allowed opposition rallies, engaged with international institutions. Tanzania joined the East African Community's single currency discussions. Foreign investment started flowing back. People thought: maybe this is a turning point. But by 2024, the backsliding was undeniable. Opposition leaders like Tundu Lissu and Freeman Mbowe were repeatedly arrested. Chadema rallies were banned. The space for dissent shrank.

Why did Hassan reverse course? Partly, it's the logic of incumbency in authoritarian systems. She needed the ruling party, Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM)—which has governed Tanzania since independence—to accept her. Magufuli loyalists within CCM didn't trust her. To consolidate power, she had to prove she'd protect the party's dominance. Allowing free elections risked losing, and losing meant criminal investigations into corruption. The incentives for rigging were overwhelming. So she did.

The economy is Hassan's other challenge. Tanzania's growth rate is solid on paper—around 5% annually—but it's not translating into broad-based prosperity. Unemployment is high, especially among youth. Inflation has eroded purchasing power. The government's debt burden is rising. Hassan touts infrastructure projects—roads, ports, railways—but critics say they're white elephants, financed by Chinese loans Tanzania can't afford. The mining sector, dominated by gold, brings in revenue but creates few jobs. Agriculture employs the majority but remains subsistence-level.

Zanzibar, Tanzania's semi-autonomous archipelago, adds complexity. Zanzibari politics are even more repressive than the mainland. The opposition CUF party faces constant harassment. Tensions over autonomy—how much power Zanzibar has versus Dodoma—simmer. The 1964 union that created Tanzania is questioned by Zanzibari activists. Hassan, who is Zanzibari herself, navigates this carefully, but it's a potential flashpoint.

Bottom line: Tanzania is sliding toward full authoritarianism. CCM's dominance, which was once justified by stability and development, now feels like stagnation and repression. Hassan had a chance to be different, and she chose the safer path of consolidation. The 2025 election was a farce, and everyone knows it. The question is whether Tanzanians will accept it. The protests suggest many won't. But without organized opposition, without international pressure, and with a ruling party willing to use violence, dissent is hard to sustain. Hassan's second term will likely be more repressive than her first. And Tanzania, once seen as a regional success story, joins the long list of African democracies that slid backward.

countries.name: Thailand
countries.summary:
Thailand's democracy is a Groundhog Day nightmare. You wake up, a reformist party wins elections, they promise change, and then—judicial coup, military intervention, or parliamentary shenanigans—they're gone. Rinse, repeat. In 2025, it happened again. Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand's youngest-ever prime minister and daughter of Thaksin Shinawatra, was removed from office by the Constitutional Court on August 29, 2025. The charge? Allegedly violating ethics codes over a conversation with Cambodian Senate President Hun Sen about the Thai-Cambodian border. It's as flimsy as it sounds, but that's how Thai politics works. The courts are weaponized. The military pulls strings. And democracy is theatre.

Paetongtarn had been PM for barely a year, taking over in August 2024 after Srettha Thavisin was himself removed by the Constitutional Court. She was supposed to be the fresh face of Pheu Thai, the party linked to the Shinawatra family, which has won every election since 2001 but never finishes a term without being deposed. The problem isn't electoral; Pheu Thai's base among rural voters is rock-solid. The problem is Thailand's entrenched elite—the military, the judiciary, the palace—who see Pheu Thai as a threat to their power. So they remove them, using courts and coups, and install compliant governments.

The real story of 2025 is the destruction of the Move Forward Party (MFP). MFP won the May 2023 election outright, taking 151 seats. Their platform was bold: reform the military, amend the lèse-majesté laws, break up monopolies. Young, urban voters flocked to them. But Thailand's Senate—appointed, not elected, and packed with military loyalists—blocked MFP from forming a government. Instead, Pheu Thai cut a deal with military-linked parties, sidelining MFP. Then, in August 2024, the Constitutional Court dissolved MFP entirely, ruling that their proposal to reform the lèse-majesté law (which criminalizes criticism of the monarchy) was unconstitutional. MFP's leaders were banned from politics for ten years. The party reformed as the People's Party, but the message was clear: challenge the system, and you'll be crushed.

Now Suriya Juangroongruangkit, a Pheu Thai figure, is acting prime minister. The coalition government is a mess. It includes Pheu Thai, the Democrat Party, and several smaller parties, but Bhumjaithai—a major partner—pulled out in May 2025 over corruption allegations. The government is weak, reliant on military-aligned parties for support, and unable to pass major legislation. Thaksin Shinawatra, the patriarch who returned from exile in August 2023, operates as a shadow figure. He's not officially in government, but everyone knows he's pulling strings. His hospital detention for corruption charges was a sham; he lives comfortably in Bangkok.

The monarchy looms over everything. King Vajiralongkorn, who ascended in 2016, is far more politically active than his father. He controls vast wealth, including the Crown Property Bureau. The lèse-majesté law is enforced brutally—people receive 15-year sentences for Facebook posts. The military, which staged coups in 2006 and 2014, positions itself as the monarchy's protector. This troika—palace, military, judiciary—is Thailand's real government. Elections determine who administers policies, but they don't determine who holds power.

The economy is a mixed bag. Tourism is recovering post-COVID, which is vital—it's 20% of GDP. But growth is sluggish, around 3%, held back by political instability and lack of investment. Inequality is stark. Bangkok thrives; the northeast remains poor. Household debt is among the highest in Asia. Pheu Thai's flagship policy, a digital wallet scheme giving 10,000 baht to citizens, is popular but fiscally reckless. The Thai baht is stable, but inflation eats into wages. Business confidence is low because nobody knows if the government will last six months.

The next election is due by May 2027, unless there's another dissolution. The People's Party (MFP rebranded) will likely win again, because the underlying political dynamics haven't changed. Young Thais want reform. They're tired of military coups and judicial interventions. But the establishment isn't budging. They'll block the People's Party, dissolve them if necessary, and install another compliant government. It's depressing, predictable, and unsustainable.

Bottom line: Thailand is trapped in a cycle of democratic façade and authoritarian control. Elections happen, but they don't determine outcomes. Courts intervene, militaries coup, and reformers are crushed. The only way out is structural change—genuinely independent courts, an elected Senate, reform of lèse-majesté laws—but the people who'd need to approve those changes are the ones benefiting from the current system. So the cycle continues. Thailand has the trappings of democracy without the substance. And until that changes, every reform government will meet the same fate as Paetongtarn: removed, sidelined, and replaced by someone who knows their place.
issues: Paetongtarn Shinawatra removed by Constitutional Court
Move Forward Party dissolved, reformed as People's Party
Cycle of coups and judicial interventions

countries.name: Tunisia
countries.summary:
Tunisia, the birthplace of the Arab Spring, is dead. Politically, at least. Kais Saïed, the president elected in 2019 on a wave of anti-establishment anger, has methodically dismantled every institution that made Tunisia the sole democratic success story of the Arab Spring. In July 2021, Saïed staged a self-coup, suspending parliament, firing the prime minister, and assuming emergency powers. He never gave them back. He rewrote the constitution in 2022—without meaningful consultation—centralizing power in the presidency. He dissolved the independent judicial council and sacked 57 judges. He arrested opposition leaders, journalists, and activists. Tunisia is now a dictatorship in all but name.

The 2024 presidential election was the final insult. Saïed won with approximately 91% of the vote, but turnout was the lowest in Tunisian history. His main opponents were either in jail, in exile, or barred from running. Kamel Eltaïef, a businessman, was sentenced to 66 years in prison in a mass trial. Khayyām Turkī, an opposition politician, got 48 years. The charges are politically motivated—corruption, "conspiracy against state security"—the usual authoritarian playbook. The election was a sham, and everyone knows it. Western governments issued statements of concern. The Tunisian public shrugged. What's the point of protesting when the president controls the courts, the police, and the military?

Saïed's ideology is bizarre—a mix of populist anti-elitism, economic nationalism, and personal paranoia. He rails against "traitors" and "conspirators," using rhetoric that incites hatred. He blames Tunisia's economic collapse on foreign plots and corrupt oligarchs, never acknowledging his own role. His speeches are long, rambling, and laced with insults. He's refused to engage with the IMF on a bailout deal, calling it neocolonialism, even as Tunisia's economy craters. Inflation is rampant. The dinar has collapsed. Basic goods—bread, milk, medicine—are in short supply. Ninety percent of Tunisians live in poverty or near-poverty. Unemployment, especially among youth, is catastrophic.

The Ennahda party, the Islamist movement that dominated post-2011 politics, is finished. Its leader, Rached Ghannouchi, is in prison, serving a 15-year sentence. Ennahda's offices are closed, its activists harassed. Civil society organizations face restrictions. The UGTT, Tunisia's powerful labor union, is one of the few institutions still capable of pushing back, but even they're cautious. Saïed has purged the security services, installing loyalists. The military, which stayed neutral during the 2011 revolution, remains apolitical—but their silence enables Saïed's authoritarianism.

The migration deal with the EU is Tunisia's economic lifeline. In 2023, the EU offered Tunisia hundreds of millions of euros in exchange for stopping migrants from crossing to Europe. Saïed took the money, cracked down on sub-Saharan migrants (often brutally), and declared victory. The EU is complicit, prioritizing migration control over democratic governance. Human rights groups document abuses—migrants abandoned in the desert, beaten by security forces, left to die. The EU looks the other way. It's a devil's bargain, and Tunisia needs the cash too desperately to refuse.

Why did Tunisia's democracy fail? Partly economics. The post-2011 democratic governments never delivered prosperity. Corruption persisted. Youth unemployment remained sky-high. The revolutionary promise of dignity and opportunity felt hollow. Saïed tapped into that frustration in 2019, running as an outsider who'd clean house. But his version of cleaning house was authoritarianism. Tunisia also lacked the institutional depth to withstand a determined autocrat. The parliament was fractious. Political parties were weak and self-interested. Civil society was vibrant but not powerful enough to check presidential overreach. When Saïed made his move in 2021, there was no organized resistance.

The international response has been pathetic. The U.S. issued statements. The EU kept negotiating migration deals. No sanctions, no real pressure. Tunisia isn't strategically vital, and the West has bigger problems—Ukraine, Gaza, China. So Saïed consolidates power, arrests opponents, and rules by decree. The Tunisian people, exhausted by economic crisis and disillusioned by politics, have largely withdrawn. Protests happen sporadically, but they're small and easily suppressed.

Bottom line: Tunisia's democratic experiment is over. Saïed has constructed a personalist regime, one that could outlast him if he builds the security apparatus to sustain it. The tragedy is how preventable this was. Tunisia had functioning institutions, active civil society, and a relatively educated population. But economic failure and elite dysfunction created the opening for Saïed's power grab. The Arab Spring's last flicker has been extinguished. What comes next is stagnation, repression, and slow-motion collapse—unless Tunisians rise up again. But revolutions are exhausting, and Tunisia has already had one. Lightning doesn't strike twice. At least, not usually.

countries.name: Turkey
countries.summary:
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is in trouble. Not existential trouble—he's survived worse—but real, grinding, approval-sapping trouble. Turkey's economy is a disaster. Inflation hit 48.6% in early 2025, and despite central bank efforts, it's still above 30% as of October. The lira has collapsed, losing two-thirds of its value since 2021. A recession officially began in 2025, with GDP contracting for two consecutive quarters. Household debt is crushing the middle class. Youth unemployment is rampant. And the cost-of-living crisis has turned even AKP loyalists skeptical. Erdoğan, who built his political brand on economic competence in the 2000s, now presides over economic mismanagement in the 2020s.

The political crisis that erupted in March 2025 made everything worse. Istanbul Mayor Ekrem İmamoğlu, Erdoğan's most popular rival and a member of the opposition CHP, was arrested on corruption charges. The move was transparently political. İmamoğlu had defeated the AKP twice in Istanbul—2019 and 2024—and was positioning himself as the CHP's presidential candidate for 2028. Erdoğan couldn't allow it. So he had İmamoğlu arrested. The response was immediate. Nationwide protests erupted. Over 1,100 people were detained. The lira plummeted further, forcing the central bank to spend $12 billion propping it up. Investor confidence evaporated. Economists warned that 21 months of orthodox monetary policy—high interest rates to combat inflation—had been undone by political instability.

Erdoğan's grip on power remains formidable. The AKP controls parliament, though their majority shrank in the 2023 elections. The judiciary is packed with loyalists. The media is tightly controlled—critical outlets are shut down, journalists jailed. The presidential system, introduced in 2018, concentrates power in Erdoğan's hands. Opposition is legal but constrained. The CHP won major cities in the March 2024 local elections—Istanbul, Ankara, Izmir—marking the largest gains against the AKP in two decades. But local victories don't translate to national power without a presidential win, and that's scheduled for 2028.

The Kurdish question is back on the agenda, sort of. The HDP, the pro-Kurdish party, was banned in 2021, replaced by the DEM Party, which continues to advocate for Kurdish rights. Its leaders are sidelined, including Selahattin Demirtaş, jailed since 2016 on terrorism charges widely seen as politically motivated. Erdoğan occasionally floats the idea of Kurdish talks, but it's cynical positioning—trying to split the opposition coalition. The southeast remains militarized. Turkey's military operations against the PKK in northern Iraq and Syria continue. The Kurdish issue is frozen, not resolved.

Foreign policy is Erdoğan's other headache. Turkey is a NATO member, but its relationship with the alliance is fraught. Erdoğan blocked Sweden's NATO accession for months, demanding concessions on Kurdish groups. He eventually relented in March 2024, but the damage to Turkey's reputation was done. Turkey's intervention in Syria—backing opposition groups, occupying territory—continues. Relations with Russia are complex: Turkey opposed Russian aggression in Ukraine but didn't join sanctions, keeping channels open for trade and diplomacy. It's a balancing act, and Western allies are skeptical of Erdoğan's commitment to the transatlantic alliance.

The 2028 presidential election is the looming question. Erdoğan, now 71, has been in power since 2003—as prime minister until 2014, then president. He'll run again, but he's weakened. İmamoğlu, if released from prison, is the CHP's strongest candidate. He's young, charismatic, and has proven he can win in tough environments. But the playing field isn't level. Erdoğan controls state resources, the media, and the judiciary. Opposition candidates face legal harassment, media blackouts, and rigged campaign rules. Still, the March 2024 local elections showed the AKP is vulnerable. If the economy doesn't improve, if inflation stays high, Erdoğan could lose. But only if the election is fair. And that's a big if.

The alternative to Erdoğan is uncertain. The CHP, Turkey's oldest party, has historically been secular and nationalist. Under Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu's leadership, they modernized, broadening their appeal. But Kılıçdaroğlu lost to Erdoğan in 2023, and the CHP needs fresh leadership. İmamoğlu or Ankara Mayor Mansur Yavaş could be that. The challenge is uniting the opposition—CHP, İYİ Party, smaller groups—behind a single candidate. In 2023, they managed it; Kılıçdaroğlu came close. In 2028, they'll need to do it again, but better.

Bottom line: Erdoğan's rule is creaking under the weight of economic failure. His authoritarian grip remains strong, but public patience is wearing thin. The 2028 election is the inflection point. If the opposition unites, if the economy stays bad, Erdoğan could lose. But don't bet against him—he's survived crises before. He'll use every tool at his disposal: state resources, media control, legal harassment. Turkey's democracy, such as it is, will be tested. The question isn't whether Erdoğan is vulnerable—he is. It's whether Turkey's institutions are strong enough to allow a fair fight. Right now, they're not. And that's the problem.
issues: Economic crisis with 30%+ inflation and recession

countries.name: Uganda
countries.summary:
Yoweri Museveni has been president of Uganda since 1986. That's 39 years. He's 81 years old, and he's running for re-election in 2026. If he wins—and he will, because Uganda's elections are never free or fair—he'll be president until 2031. By then, he'll be 87. This isn't democracy; it's gerontocracy with ballots. And yet, Uganda goes through the motions. Campaigns happen, rallies are held, and everyone pretends the outcome isn't predetermined. It's exhausting political theatre.

The opposition knows it, but they're fighting anyway. Bobi Wine, the musician-turned-politician whose real name is Robert Kyagulanyi Ssentamu, was cleared by Uganda's Electoral Commission in September 2025 to run against Museveni. Wine leads the National Unity Platform (NUP), which holds nine of ten parliamentary seats in Kampala. In the 2021 election, Wine defeated Museveni in the capital by over 28,000 votes. But nationally, Museveni "won" with 58.6% of the vote in an election marred by violence, internet shutdowns, and mass arrests. International observers called it neither free nor fair. The same will happen in 2026.

Wine launched his campaign in October 2025 with a nationwide tour, aiming to mobilize 20 million voters. His rallies draw huge crowds—even in NRM strongholds like Butaleja in eastern Uganda, thousands braved rain to hear him speak. The NRM tried to dismiss it as "celebrity magic," comparing Wine's appeal to a musical concert. But the crowds aren't just fans; they're frustrated Ugandans tired of corruption, unemployment, and repression. Wine's message is simple: it's time for change. The problem is that Museveni controls the military, the police, the Electoral Commission, and the judiciary. Changing a leader who controls everything is nearly impossible.

Museveni's NRM (National Resistance Movement) has governed since the end of Uganda's civil wars in 1986. For the first two decades, Museveni was praised as a reformer—stabilizing the country, growing the economy, fighting HIV/AIDS. But power corrupts. Constitutional amendments in 2005 removed term limits. In 2017, age limits were removed, allowing Museveni to run indefinitely. The parliament that passed these amendments was packed with NRM loyalists, many of whom received cash payments—literal bribes—to vote yes. Uganda's democracy, such as it was, died then. What remains is a façade.

The opposition is harassed constantly. Bobi Wine has been arrested dozens of times. His rallies are teargassed. His supporters are beaten. In November 2024, Kizza Besigye, another veteran opposition leader, disappeared while visiting Kenya, only to reappear in a Ugandan military court, accused of seeking weapons. The charge was absurd, denied by Besigye, but it didn't matter. The point was intimidation. The military and police act with impunity. Human rights organizations document abuses, but Museveni dismisses them as foreign interference.

Corruption is endemic. Uganda's oil reserves, discovered in 2006 and finally approaching production, were supposed to transform the economy. Instead, they've become a source of graft. Contracts are awarded to Museveni allies. Environmental safeguards are ignored. The East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP), a massive project running from Uganda to Tanzania, faces international criticism for displacement of communities and environmental damage. But Museveni pushes ahead because oil revenue will entrench his regime.

Uganda's military role in the region props up Museveni domestically. Ugandan troops are deployed in Somalia as part of ATMIS (African Transition Mission in Somalia), fighting al-Shabaab. They're also in the Democratic Republic of Congo, combating the ADF (Allied Democratic Forces), an Islamist insurgency. These deployments keep the military busy and loyal—officers get UN allowances, and the UPDF (Uganda People's Defence Force) maintains its reputation as a regional powerhouse. The military is Museveni's ultimate insurance policy. As long as the generals are paid and deployed, they won't turn on him.

The 2026 election will be a farce. Museveni will "win" with around 60% of the vote. The NRM will dominate parliament. International observers will document irregularities. Western governments will issue statements of concern. And nothing will change. The question isn't whether Museveni wins in 2026—it's what happens when he dies. He's 81, in apparently good health, but mortality is undefeated. Uganda has no succession plan. Museveni's son, Muhoozi Kainugaba, a general in the UPDF, is positioning himself as heir, tweeting provocatively and building a political base. But military succession is unpredictable. Rival factions could emerge. A power vacuum in Uganda could be destabilizing, not just for Uganda but for the region.

Bottom line: Uganda is an authoritarian state masquerading as a democracy. Elections are held, but they're rigged. Opposition exists, but it's repressed. Bobi Wine represents hope for millions of Ugandans, especially the young, but hope doesn't win elections when the deck is stacked. Museveni will remain in power until he dies or is overthrown, and overthrow seems unlikely while the military is loyal. Uganda's politics are frozen. The tragedy is that Uganda has potential—natural resources, a young population, regional influence. But potential without accountable leadership is just wasted opportunity. And Uganda has wasted nearly four decades.
issues: Bobi Wine's opposition campaign and NUP strength

countries.name: Ukraine
countries.summary:
Volodymyr Zelenskyy is exhausted, and so is Ukraine. Nearly four years into the war with Russia, Ukraine is still fighting, still standing, but the optimism of 2022—when Ukraine repelled Russia's assault on Kyiv and recaptured Kharkiv—feels like a distant memory. The front lines have barely moved in a year. The counteroffensive in summer 2023 failed. Casualties are mounting. Western aid is inconsistent. And now, with Donald Trump back in the White House, Ukraine faces its most uncertain moment since the invasion began.

The Trump-Zelenskyy relationship is toxic. In late February 2025, Zelenskyy traveled to Washington for a high-stakes meeting with Trump. It devolved into a shouting match. Trump and Vice President JD Vance berated Zelenskyy, falsely blaming him for the war and demanding Ukraine accept Russia's terms: cede the entire Donbas region, drop NATO aspirations, and declare victory. Trump's ultimatum was blunt: "You're either going to make a deal or we're out." Without U.S. support, Ukraine can't sustain the war. European aid helps, but it's not enough. The U.S. provides the bulk of military equipment—HIMARS, Patriots, artillery shells, intelligence. If that stops, Ukraine's defensive capabilities collapse.

Trump's pressure isn't subtle. He called Zelenskyy a "dictator" for not holding elections, ignoring the fact that Ukraine's constitution prohibits elections during martial law. He met with Vladimir Putin multiple times, pursuing a deal that would effectively reward Russian aggression. Trump's worldview sees Ukraine as a distraction from U.S.-China competition. He wants the war "solved"—meaning Ukraine concedes territory—so he can focus elsewhere. European leaders, horrified by Trump's approach, have rallied behind Zelenskyy. Kaja Kallas, the EU's foreign policy chief, said bluntly: "It became clear today that the free world needs a new leader." Zelenskyy received a warm welcome in London, Berlin, and Paris. But European support, while morally gratifying, doesn't replace American firepower.

Ukraine's domestic politics are under strain. Zelenskyy governs under martial law, which suspends normal political processes. The Verkhovna Rada (parliament) functions, but many MPs are at the front or involved in defense roles. Political unity, strong in 2022, is fraying. There are tensions between Zelenskyy and military leadership. General Valerii Zaluzhnyi, the popular Commander-in-Chief, was replaced in February 2024 with Oleksandr Syrskyi after disagreements over strategy. Zaluzhnyi is now Ukraine's ambassador to the UK, sidelined but still influential. Rumors of a 2026 presidential challenge persist, though elections remain postponed due to war.

Corruption remains a persistent issue. Ukraine has made genuine reforms—transparent procurement systems, anti-corruption bureaus—but wartime procurement offers temptations. Scandals involving defense contracts surfaced in 2024, leading to arrests. Zelenskyy moved quickly to prosecute, knowing that Western aid depends on showing accountability. But the perception that elites profit while ordinary Ukrainians suffer is corrosive. Mobilization is another flashpoint. Ukraine lowered the draft age and intensified conscription drives in 2024-25. Men of fighting age can't leave the country. Draft dodging is common. The population is tired. Everyone knows someone who's died.

The war's trajectory is unclear. Ukraine holds the line but lacks the manpower and equipment for major offensives. Russia, meanwhile, has adapted. Its economy, though strained by sanctions, hasn't collapsed. Putin has shifted to a war economy, ramping up military production. North Korea supplies artillery shells. Iran provides drones. China offers tacit economic support. Russian casualties are staggering—estimates suggest 200,000+ dead—but Putin shows no sign of stopping. He believes time is on his side: Ukraine will tire, Western support will wane, and eventually Ukraine will accept Russia's terms.

Zelenskyy's position is that Ukraine won't cede territory. Donbas and Crimea are Ukrainian, he insists, and any peace deal must include their return. But that's maximalist. The reality is Ukraine may have to accept a frozen conflict—Russia occupies 18% of Ukrainian territory, a ceasefire is declared, and the issue is left unresolved for decades, like Korea. Zelenskyy's domestic support depends on not conceding defeat, but if the alternative is endless war without Western backing, pragmatism may force his hand.

European NATO allies are stepping up. Poland is massively increasing defense spending. The Baltics, Nordic countries, and France are providing more aid. The UK remains Ukraine's staunchest supporter. But Europe can't replace the U.S., especially on air defense and long-range strike capabilities. The Trump administration's signaling has emboldened Putin. If the U.S. withdraws support, Ukraine faces a grim choice: fight on with diminished capacity or negotiate from weakness.

Bottom line: Ukraine's future hinges on American politics. If Trump forces a deal that cedes territory, Ukraine loses, and the post-war order fractures. If Europe and Ukraine hold the line despite U.S. pressure, the war grinds on. Zelenskyy is gambling that Trump's deal collapses under European and congressional opposition. It's a dangerous gamble. Ukraine has fought heroically, but heroism without ammunition doesn't win wars. The next year will determine whether Ukraine survives as a sovereign, independent state or becomes a Russian vassal. It's existential, and Zelenskyy knows it. So does everyone else.
issues: Tense U.S.-Ukraine relations after shouting match
European support vs. U.S. withdrawal risk
